b'Zero carbon, zero waste for advertising production is the ultimate objective for AdGreen - a new sustainability initiative launched by the Climate Action Working Group with the support of Unilever, Sky, WPP, Havas, adam&eveDDB and MullenLowe Group.

The project has two main aims: to measure the impact advertising production has on the environment, and to identify which activities leave the heaviest carbon footprint. 
 
\xe2\x80\x9cUltimately, AdGreen means everyone producing advertising work will be able to capture and understand their own footprint data; advertisers and advertising agencies will be able to compare that to anonymised benchmarks,\xe2\x80\x9d explains Jo Coombes, Founder of AdGreen. \xe2\x80\x9cWe want to build a future-proofed carbon literate workforce, giving us the opportunity for the highest creative ambition with the lowest carbon impact.\xe2\x80\x9d 

AdGreen hopes to empower the advertising production industry to measure, manage and ultimately reduce its carbon footprint by developing a calculator, specialist training, a renewable energy buy-in scheme, and later, certification and a high-quality offsetting scheme. 

\xe2\x80\x9cWhat we do today is make or break,\xe2\x80\x9d says Alan Jope, CEO Unilever. \xe2\x80\x9dSo we\xe2\x80\x99re delighted to join our peers and other leading organisations to launch AdGreen, to push for real change in advertising production. Now is the time to commit to a fairer, zero-carbon world.\xe2\x80\x9d

b'\xe2\x80\x9cOn 24 March, the government of India ordered a nationwide lockdown, limiting the movement of 1.3 billion people. Migrant workers from all over India found themselves stranded. Bangalore is a technology hub and a prosperous city, with many migrants and daily wage labourers. 
There was this one dog \xe2\x80\x93 old, blind and immobile \xe2\x80\x93 whom I used to feed on my commute to the office. But I realised that day that the problem was much bigger than one dog: there were a lot of stray animals and migrants without access to food and drinking water. I discussed the situation with my family and the idea to cook food for them came into my mind. What initially started with 30\xe2\x80\x9340 people and a few stray dogs grew overnight. To accommodate this number, I took space in a commercial kitchen, offered free of charge, and cooked food for 500+ people and 80+ stray animals every day during the first two periods of lockdown. People spread the word and contributed cash, fruit, groceries and dog food. 
Never in my wildest of dreams did I imagine that one day I would be cooking for so many people, alongside my husband and a young helper. I started my day at 6.30 am and ended after midnight, but it was worth all the effort. 
All this would definitely not have been possible without the support of my family and Unilever colleagues. They also provided funding to supplement the money that I gave personally. A heartfelt thank you to them. As we are all fighting this battle together, I would ask everyone: care for your neighbourhood and surroundings, as people are really in need. A little food and water, along with some humanity and kindness, is the need of the hour.\xe2\x80\x9d Ranjani Shettigar
